name: Actinic Keratosis
description: A precancerous skin condition caused by long-term sun exposure. It appears as rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas and has the potential to develop into squamous cell carcinoma.
next_steps: Regular dermatological examinations
Treatment to prevent progression to cancer
Strict sun protection measures

name: Basal Cell Carcinoma
description: A common and slow-growing form of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells in the epidermis. Often appears as a pearly or waxy bump, a flat flesh-colored lesion, or a sore that doesn't heal.
next_steps: Consult a dermatologist for a biopsy
Follow up with regular skin checks
Use sun protection to prevent recurrence

name: Benign Keratosis-like Lesions
description: A non-cancerous skin condition that includes seborrheic keratoses, solar lentigines, and lichen planus-like keratoses. These lesions may appear as rough, scaly, or pigmented patches.
next_steps: Dermatological evaluation to rule out malignancy
Monitoring for changes in size, shape, or color
Removal if symptomatic or for cosmetic reasons

name: Dermatofibroma
description: A benign skin growth that appears as a firm, raised nodule, usually on the legs. It is often skin-colored or pigmented and may dimple when pinched.
next_steps: Consult a dermatologist if growth changes or causes discomfort
Monitor for any increase in size or unusual symptoms

name: Melanoma
description: A dangerous form of skin cancer that originates in the pigment-producing melanocytes. It often appears as a new or changing mole with asymmetry, irregular borders, color variations, a diameter larger than 6mm, and evolving features.
treatment: Sentinel lymph node biopsy if advanced
Radiation or chemotherapy in advanced cases
next_steps: Immediate dermatological evaluation and biopsy
Staging to determine spread
Treatment plan based on stage and mutation status
Routine skin checks for early detection of recurrence

name: Melanocytic Nevi
description: Commonly known as moles, melanocytic nevi are benign skin growths caused by clusters of melanocytes. They can be congenital or acquired and vary in size and color.
treatment: Surgical excision if atypical or changing
next_steps: Regular self-examination for any changes
Dermatological check-ups if new or changing moles appear
Sun protection to reduce new mole formation

name: Vascular Lesions
description: A group of benign skin conditions that include cherry angiomas, hemangiomas, and vascular malformations. They appear as red, purple, or blue discolorations on the skin.
next_steps: Dermatological evaluation if lesion changes or bleeds
Treatment for cosmetic or medical concerns
